title: Boeing to produce high-tech airplane systems in Oregon
text: Boeing said the facility “will manufacture and assemble flap actuation systems for the… more Courtesy of Boeing Boeing will manufacture and assemble key parts of its “Next Generation” planes at its plant in Gresham, the company announced today. The company said the move wouldn’t expand employment at the Gresham plant, which it calls Boeing Portland, where it employs more than 1,600 people. The new work, though, ensures a stable workforce even as the plant grows more productive, said Don Hendrickson , program manager on the project. Boeing said the facility “will manufacture and assemble flap actuation systems for the… more Courtesy of Boeing “If you don’t bring in new work, your size shrinks,” Hendrickson said. Boeing said the facility “will manufacture and assemble flap actuation systems for the Next Generation 737, 737 MAX and 777, expanding Boeing Portland’s work statement for the company’s commercial airplane production." The company said the components were previously manufactured and assembled by suppliers. The move follows a recent trend of investment in the local Boeing operation. The company revealed in 2010 it would spend $100 million to fortify its Portland operations. That strategy came three years after the city of Gresham signed-off on a Boeing request that led to an $80 million investment in the site. In January 2016, Boeing said it "continues to make investments in our facility for future production rate increases." This story will be updated. Pete Danko covers energy, manufacturing and ports.
